newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Wisconsin wants other Asia-Pacific deals.
newsitem.headline: Wisconsin wants other Asia-Pacific deals.

text.p: Wisconsin Central Transportation Corp President and Chief Executive Edward Burkhardt said on Tuesday the U.S. railroad company was looking for more opportunities in the Asia Pacific region.
"We are always interested in growth opportunities," he told Reuters.
Wisconsin purchased a major stake in New Zealand Rail, now Tranz Rail, in 1993 when it was privatisated.
"I see that (privatisation) as coming on strong in Asia-Pacific, but not only there, it's a worldwide phenomena," Burkhardt said. "Our purchase in Britain was part of that."
Wisconsin recently purchased four of five rail freight companies that were privatised in Britain and is interested in acquiring the sixth.
Burkhardt said Wisconsin was particularly interested in Australia and Malaysia, where it expects rail to privatisated.
"We certainly would be looking at that. The change of commonwealth government in Australia is going to make all types of privatisations much more likely."
However, he noted most of Australia's railways are owned by the states in Australia.

"I see more opportunities today in the operations the Federal Government is involved in there -- Australia National and National Rail," he said. "We would look at them or if any state operations were put on the market there."
He said Malaysia had taken taken a few tentative steps towards rail privatisation and Wisconsin was following developments closely.

Burkhardt said Wisconsin had been pleased with its New Zealand purchase, a much cleaner buy than in Britain. The latter was complicated because the rail infrastructure was spun off into a different company to the passenger and freight companies.
"They (Britain) set up a regime that is very costly in assessing charges against the operators to support the infrastructure company.
"All of this is totally foreign to the way railway companies operate in North America and New Zealand. It has taken some getting used."
Wisconsin is in the process of cutting the staff in the British companies by half from 75,000.
"The New Zealand system was much better run and had a much more successful history up till the date of privatisation than the British system had."
Burkhardt said any fresh purchase would be funded from a combination of debt and equity.
There were opportunities for Tranz Rail to work in a joint venture with Wisconsin.

There were limits to Wisconsin's ability to manage dispersed railway companies and Tranz Rail with its history of successful transformation from state-owned company to commercial operation could use its experience.
"Between the two of us, we can magnify our management resources in looking at these bigger transactions," Burkhardt said. -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
